title: 107_s22
content: The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, limits on soft money of national political party committees, and miscellaneous provisions. It mandates additional disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, increased electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also sets limits on soft money, allows for judicial review, and increases contribution limits. The Act includes provisions for disclosure, limits on soft money of national political party committees, and miscellaneous provisions such as prohibiting solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings and updating penalty amounts. It also mandates additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports. The Act mandates additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports for Principal Campaign Committees, with specific deadlines for filing. The Act requires quarterly reports to be filed by the treasurer of a political party not later than the 15th day after the end of each calendar quarter, with the exception of the report for the quarter ending December 31, which must be filed by January 31 of the following year. Additionally, a national committee of a political party must file the required reports. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national committees of political parties to file monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national committees of political parties to file monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. Section 309(b) is also amended to change "calendar quarter" to "month". National political party committees are now required to file monthly reports instead of quarterly reports, as per the amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. Political committees must separately itemize reporting for any person with receipts or disbursements exceeding $200 in a calendar year. Reporting periods are specified for filing reports. The political committee must separately itemize reporting for individuals with receipts or disbursements over $200 in a calendar year, following the same reporting periods as required for political committees. SEC. 103 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104 mandates public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make available for public inspection a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including whether the request is accepted or rejected, the rate charged, air date and time, class of time purchased, and details of the candidate or issue referenced in the communication. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including details such as the candidate's name, authorized committee, treasurer, and contact information for the person purchasing the time. Licensees must keep a record of executives or board members and place this information in a political file promptly, retaining it for at least 2 years. SEC. 105. SOFTWARE FOR FILING OF REPORTS. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the development and free distribution of software for filing designations, statements, or reports. Users must use this software for filing as required. SEC. 201. LIMIT ON SOFT MONEY OF NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Amendment to Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to impose limits on soft money contributions by national political party committees. The provision imposes limits on donations to political party committees, restricting individuals from donating more than $60,000 in a calendar year. Additionally, it sets an aggregate limit on disbursements by individuals at $60,000 annually, with adjustments based on the price index after 2001. The provision sets limits on donations to political party committees, capping individual donations at $60,000 per calendar year. Amounts are adjusted annually based on the price index after 2001. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Members of Congress, candidates, political party committees, or affected individuals can challenge the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals of court decisions can be directly made to the Supreme Court within specific timeframes. Expedited Review: Appeals of court decisions regarding the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act can be made directly to the Supreme Court within specific timeframes. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court are required to expedite the disposition of such matters to the greatest extent possible. Enforcement of section 324 is stayed from the filing of an action under subsection (a) until the final disposition of the case. Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act is stayed from the filing of an action under subsection (a) until the final disposition of the case by the Supreme Court of the United States, with a 30-day limit for filing such actions after the effective date of the Act. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in Individual and Political Committee Contribution Limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with adjustments to the limits for different categories like $3,000, $60,000, $15,000, and $75,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to increase multicandidate limits, with adjustments to contribution limits for different categories like $7,500, $30,000, and $15,000. Additionally, a new provision is added for national committees of political parties exceeding $15,000 in aggregate contributions to candidates and their authorized committees for Federal office elections. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase multicandidate limits and adjust contribution limits for different categories. A new provision is added for national committees of political parties exceeding $15,000 in aggregate contributions to candidates and their authorized committees for Federal office elections. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase multicandidate limits and adjust contribution limits for different categories. A new provision is added for national committees of political parties exceeding $15,000 in aggregate contributions to candidates and their authorized committees for Federal office elections. Subsequently, limitations established by subsections (a), (b), (d), or (h) are increased by a determined percent difference, remaining in effect for the calendar year. Amounts increased under this provision will remain in effect for a 2-year period starting after the last general election preceding the increase. Additionally, the definition of calendar year 1974 is revised for subsections (b) and (d) to mean calendar year 1974, and for subsections (a) and (h) to mean calendar year 2001. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for Senate candidates and national party committees. The amendments apply to calendar years starting after December 31, 2001, with specific provisions for different subsections. The contribution limit for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees is increased from $17,500 to $60,000. The definition of calendar year 1974 is revised for subsections (b) and (d) to mean calendar year 1974, and for subsections (a) and (h) to mean calendar year 2001. SEC. 301 prohibits the solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define "contribution" in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. Section 602(a)(4) is also amended to include a prohibition on donations. Section 602(a)(4) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a prohibition on donations from any State, district, or local committee of a political party. SEC. 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation based on the price index. SEC. 303 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require all designations, statements, and reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. Conforming amendments are made to ensure proper filing procedures.
